title: How To Easily Find Your Twitter Network on Mastodon - STILL WORKING!

last_post.content:
TRYING TO FIND YOUR OLD TWITTER NETWORK?

After the great API shutoff, a lot of the services that people have been utilising to find their old Twitter networks no longer work.

Fedifinder is one of the few that is still up and running (I confirmed it myself this morning).

It isn't as seamless as some of the older methods, but can still be used in mere minutues to find users and easily follow them on Mastodon using the Import feature.

This video guide walks through the whole process from start to finish.

Please #Boost this to spread the word around your networks as much as possible. :ablobcatbongopost:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=37S246Wr_JE

#Fedifinder #MastodonTips #FediTips #TwitterMigration #Twitter

Noa Kallioinen gave a short tutorial on how to do prior and likelihood sensitivity analysis (prior sensitivity can be due to prior-likelihood conflict or due to a weak likelihood) with `priorsense` R package in Bayes@Lund and the 18min video is now available https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TBXD3HjcIps&list=PLUEhQLNNQrgndd7_ZY-U5x9lYssl25jmd&index=13

title: These Fossils Were Supposed To Be Impossible

last_post.content:
Charnwood Forest, Leicestershire, England, circa 560 million years ago. A fossil found here in 1956 by a local, Tina Negus, turned out to be the first solid evidence that complex lifeforms existed before the Cambrian Period. Subsequent discoveries hint that the site was a deep-water environment hosting a myriad of organisms.

Watch the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ipkBmbi6k5c

The Topos Institute is starting a book club for Eugenia Cheng's marvelous intro to category theory! They'll go at a rate of one chapter per week, and you're all invited to submit questions. Eugenia Cheng will make a video each week addressing the questions for that chapter. Questions on chapter 1 are due February 19th.

Questioners will remain anonymous, so don’t hesitate to ask questions that might feel “stupid”.

For more about the book, try this:

https://youtu.be/96t4dFSm0Xk

(1/n)

Big data visualization is about quoting less-aggregated data.

This network can be seen without 3D glasses. But with it, by just blinking, you can switch from the aggregated annotation layer to the less-aggregated original data, a network of expressions from academic papers about AI in science.

You can look "inside" the aggregation, and possibly challenge it. The same way quoting a text allows the reader to challenge what *you* say it says.

https://youtu.be/4m9IuW3yGkk

What is the greatest unknown, if not the universe itself? It seemed natural, therefore, to chose an image of the universe as the source for the new video of "Unknow", a piece for piano, bass, contrabass, electronic drums, and oud, dedicated to the homonym character by Magnus (Roberto Raviola). You can freely download the song in lossless format from https://eidon.bandcamp.com/track/unknow

"Unknow" is one of my "imaginary soundtracks" -- soundtracks for movies, or cartoons, which actually... do not exist (yet). Here I try to represent the strain of a life in perennial flight from the perils of the present and the horror of the past. The "fugato" in the piece corresponds to this flight -- this fugue state, if you allow me the pun.

If you like this piece, follow me on Bandcamp: https://eidon.bandcamp.com/follow_me on youtube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCZ0UIBDZEYlvn8thxv3aOxw, and FB, https://www.facebook.com/EidonVeda.

Video is a zoom out of "Tapestry of Blazing Starbirth" (https://esahubble.org/images/heic2007a/), a NASA/ESA/Hubble picture. Credit: NASA, ESA, and STScI. License: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/
The video consists of portions of the original image, scaled down to a frame size of 900x618 pixels.

The video was created with veemadge (https://gitlab.com/Eidonko/veemadge). It can be watche also on #youtube: https://youtu.be/Bq0nEhlJoME.

The music is by and (c) Eidon (Eidon at tutanota.com, Eidon.Songs at gmail.com). All rights reserved.

title: The Great Simplification | Film on Energy, Environment, and Our Future | FULL MOVIE

last_post.content:
The Great Simplification

Modern society is driven by a stored carbon energy battery, a battery which is being rapidly depleted. As energy becomes more expensive to access, the economy will shrink, things will become simpler. The process will be traumatic.

Looking forward to watching Theresa Jean Tanenbaum's talk on trans game studies:

"In this talk I argue that game design - like magic and activism - is a framework for invoking and materializing seemingly impossible desires for ourselves, and our world. Within the "magic circles" of both play and witchcraft we assert truths about the world that are decoupled from the often-arbitrary rules and power structures that govern daily life."

title: I invented a new way to answer horrible comments

This is the best way to respond to mean comments online.

First, buy a harp. Second, program strings to correspond to letters. Third, type your comments on the harp.

Folks in #tech should take notes from these presentations, they are a master class in thinking about not just modeling but also how to present useful predictions. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Sw29Ta5MWbY (3/3) #AI #HCI

title: Lankum - Go Dig My Grave (Official Video)

last_post.content: The new Lankum album is coming out in less than two months and wowza it’s sounding good. Extremely depressing, but exquisite https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qhqpQiXnFx0

What do we mean when we talk about "quality content"? And why is quality even important to get right?

When we fixate on tools, frameworks, or checklists - we forget what marketing is supposed to be for.

Who are you marketing to?

What are you trying to achieve with your marketing?

You cannot answer either of those questions without a deep understanding of who you are and who you are speaking to.

See more in my new video: https://youtu.be/6uYJXv0istw
